textline.text: Daniel Aldana Cohen
Curriculum Vitae
September 1st, 2015
PhD Candidate, Department of Sociology
New York University
295 Lafayette Street, 4 FL, New York NY, 10012
aldanacohen@nyu.edu
www.aldanacohen.com
Education
2016 (expected)
PhD Candidate in Sociology, New York University
Dissertation title: Street Fight: Urban Climate Politics in an Age of Finance and Revolt
Dissertation chair: Craig Calhoun. Committee and readers: Gianpaolo
Baiocchi, Neil Brenner, Eric Klinenberg, Jeff Manza
Visiting Scholar, Centro de Estudos da Metropole, São Paulo (September to
December)
PhD Student in History (Latin America), New York University
Bachelor of Arts, First Class Honours, McGill University
Joint Honours in Intellectual History and Development Studies
International Diploma, L’Institut d’études politiques de Paris
Peer-reviewed journal articles
“The rationed city: The politics of water, housing, and land use in drought-parched
São Paulo” Public Culture, 28:2. In press.
“New York City as ‘fortress of solitude’ after Hurricane Sandy: A relational sociology of extreme
weather’s impact on climate politics”
Under review: Environmental Politics.
“Grey ecologies and red-green alliance: Housing movements and climate politics in a global city.”
Preparing for submission to International Journal of Urban and Regional Research in October.
“The Environmentalization of Desirability: Linking ecological upgrading and social displacement in the
capitalist city.” With Hillary Angelo and Gianpaolo Baiocchi.
Preparing for submission to Qualitative Sociology in December.
Books: edited and chapters
Forthcoming
Petro-Gotham, People’s Gotham. In Rebecca Solnit and Joshua Jelly-Shapiro eds.
Impossible Metropolis: A New York City Atlas. Berkeley: University of California Press.
Expected publication: Fall 2016.
Forthcoming The Other Low-Carbon Protagonists: Popular Housing Movements and Climate
Politics in a Global City. In Miriam Greenberg and Penny Luce eds. The City is the
: Social Movements in the Age of Neoliberal Urbanism. Ithaca: Cornell University Press.
Factory
Expected publication: Fall 2016.
Forthcoming Urban Policy and Planning for Climate Change. In Alison Bain and Linda Peake eds.
Urbanization In A Global Context: A Canadian Perspective. Oxford: Oxford University Press.
Expected publication: Fall 2016.
Notes from Canada’s Young Activists: A Generation Stands Up for Change. Co-editor. Vancouver:
Douglas & McIntyre.
Winner, Gold Medal for Activism/Charity from Annual Living Now Book
Awards.
“Put Your Money Where Your Carbon Is: The Green Property Tax” (with David
Wachsmuth). GreenTOpia: Reimagining Green in Toronto: 54-55. Toronto: Coach House Press.
Forget fertility, get feral. Review: George Monbiot’s Feral: Rewilding the Land, the Sea, and
Human Life. In Public Books. (www.publicbooks.org), 1 February.
Review: From Precaution to Proﬁt: Contemporary Challenges to Environmental Protection in the
Montreal Protocol by Brian J. Gareau. 2013. In Journal of World-Systems Research. (19)2,
Counterpower’s Long Game. Review: Manuel Castells’ Networks of Outrage and Hope. In
Public Books. (www.publicbooks.org), 18 March.
Book reviews
Other selected publications
Interview: How Shorter Work Hours Can Help the Climate and Women’s Equality.
Interview with Tom Malleson. Labor Notes. March, 10-11. Republished online by In
These Times and Truth-Out.
Is Climate Change Big or Small? Dissent magazine online. New York: 13 November.
New York’s Two Sandys. with Max Liboiron. Metropolics. www.metropolitiques.eu.
(Online, peer-reviewed journal of research syntheses). 20 October 2014.
Seize the Hamptons: We should all get the chance to escape the city and enjoy leisure —
without the hefty ecological footprint. Jacobin. October, 151-159.
A Tale of Two Sandys. White paper. With Superstorm Research Lab. New York.
http://superstormresearchlab.org/white-paper
A most people’s climate movement? After Rio+20, Brazil’s climate justice
movement struggles to deepen its roots. NACLA Report on the Americas, (46)1, 50-54
Democracy or eco-apartheid. Center for Humans and Nature online forum on climate
change and democracy. (www.humansandnature.org), 6 February.
Were March 1st Demonstrators Occupy’s Comeback Kids? Social Science Research
Council, Possible Futures (www.possiblefutures.org). 9 March.
Amorous Analogies: How #OWS Connects the Dots. Social Science Research Council,
Possible Futures (www.possiblefutures.org). 23 December.
A Mouse Eye View of Eviction Night. Social Science Research Council, Possible Futures
www.possiblefutures.org). 23 November.
The Dictatorship of No Alternatives: Progressive economists are rethinking markets.
Book review essay. The Walrus magazine (Toronto), January/February.
Coca Si, Cocaína No: The struggle to legitimize the coca leaf (written in Bolivia). The
magazine (Toronto), January/February.
Review: Sewing the Seeds of a New World Agriculture. Canadian Dimension
magazine (Winnipeg), November/December.
Bolivia’s Water Fight. The Walrus online (Toronto), October.
Walrus
Awards and fellowships
Research and writing
Research award to conduct ﬁeldwork on São Paulo's water crisis. New York University,
Institute for Public Knowledge. $3000.
Research award, New York University, Institute for Public Knowledge, for project
“Fortress of Solitude” nested in the Superstorm Research Lab. $1500.
Fellowship, Hertog Global Strategy Initiative’s summer seminar, “The History and Future
of Climate Change and Global Governance,” Columbia University, May-August, $4000.
Green Grant, New York University, Ofﬁce of Sustainability, for Superstorm Research
Lab. $13,056. (Co-principal investigator).
Research award, New York University, Institute for Public Knowledge, for project “The
Urban Politics of Climate Change” nested in the Superstorm Research Lab, $2500. (Co-
principal investigator).
Doctoral fellowship, Social Science and Humanities Research Council of Canada,
$80,000 over four years.
MacCracken Fellowship, New York University, full tuition, health beneﬁts, and annual
stipend of approximately $24,000 per annum.
Summer research grant, Sociology Department, New York University. $2,000.
Canadian International Development Agency: Journalism Development
Initiative, $6,500.
Toronto Arts Council: Project Grant for Emerging Writer, $2000.
McConnell tuition scholarship, McGill University, $20,000 over four years
Canada-EU Studies grant to study at Sciences-Po in Paris, $2,400
Travel
Travel grant. Center for Social and Political Behavior (New York University). To present
at the ISA Research Committee 21 urban studies conference. $1000.
Travel grant. Department of sociology. To present at the American Association of
Sociologists and the ISA Research Committee 21 urban studies conference. $850.
Dean’s Travel Grant. Graduate School of Arts and Sciences. To present at the American
Association of Sociologists. $500.
Travel grant. Center for Social and Political Behavior (New York University). To present
at the International Sociology Association’s international conference. $1000.
Travel grant. Institute for Public Knowledge. To present at the International Sociology
Association’s international conference, $1000.
Collective research projects
superstormresearchlab.org. Collective research project on the aftermath of
2012-ongoing Co-principal investigator, Superstorm Research Lab.
Hurricane Sandy. Hosted by the Institute for Public Knowledge, New York
University. Funded by the Institute for Public Knowledge and the New York
University Ofﬁce of Sustainability.
www.
Proﬁle in NextCity, featuring interview with Daniel Aldana Cohen.
“Disaster Sociologists Study How Hurricane Sandy Changed Life in New
York.” 7 August, 2014. <http://nextcity.org/daily/entry/disaster-
sociologists-study-how-hurricane-sandy-changed-life-in-new-york>
Feature television interview on New York 1 evening news, featuring
interview with Daniel Aldana Cohen. “Superstorm Expert Discusses
Sandy's Impact on New Yorkers.” 4 October, 2014. <http://
www.ny1.com/content/spotlight/in_the_spotlight/216669/superstorm-
expert-discusses-sandy-s-impact-on-new-yorkers.>
2014-ongoing Research assistant. Rebuild by Design (hosted at Institute for Public Knowledge). Assisting
in development and coordination of Design and Politics: Understanding Global
Resiliency. a selective global working group of leading resiliency researchers and
practitioners. <www.rebuildbydesign.org>
Co-organizer, Democratizing the Green City 2014 speaker series, co-hosted
by the Institute for Public Knowledge and the Urban Democracy Lab at NYU.
http://gallatin.nyu.edu/utilities/events/2014/03/greencity.html>
Co-organizer, Institute for Public Knowledge's Cities, Cultures, and Climate
Change Working Group. <https://ipk.nyu.edu/working-groups/cities>
“Research Methods,” New York University, College of Arts and Sciences, summer.
“Tutorial: Global Fellowship in Urban Practice.” New York University, Gallatin School of
Individualized Study, spring.
“Sociology of gender” New York University, College of Arts and Sciences, summer.
“Introduction to sociology”, New York University, College of Arts and Sciences, fall.
“Texts and Ideas: Antiquity and the 19th century,” New York University, Morse
Academic Plan, fall.
Teaching
Instructor
Teaching assistant
Presentations at professional meetings and conferences
Understanding São Paulo’s drought. Land & Water Conference. Brown University.
Providence: September 4-5.
It’s the collective consumption, stupid. Re-theorizing urban ecological politics and
the composition of front-line communities. Research Committee 21 conference on
urban studies. Urbino, Italy: August 27-29.
The Environmentalization of Desirability: Linking ecological upgrading and social
displacement in the capitalist city. First author. Co-authors Hillary Angelo and
Gianpaolo Baiocchi. Chicago: August 22-25.
It’s the collective consumption, stupid. Re-theorizing urban ecological politics and
the composition of front-line communities. Dimensions of Political Ecology
conference. Lexington, Kentucky: February 26-28.
A tale of two compact cities: Green policy elites, poor people’s movements, and low-
carbon policy stagnation in a global city. (Roundtable.) American Sociological
Association. San Francisco: August 16-19.
How Global City Labor Markets Are Undermining Low-Carbon Policymaking.
International Sociological Association annual conference: Yokohama, Japan. July 13-19.
Beyond Metonymia: A Social Backcast Approach to Urban Climate Politics.
Association of American Geographers annual conference, Tampa Bay. April 9.
Fortress of Solitude: New York’s Climate Parochialism After Sandy. NYU Sociology
Graduate Conference. New York: April 4.
Fortress of Solitude: New York’s Climate Parochialism After Sandy. NYLON annual
conference, New York: March 28.
Fortress of Solitude: New York’s Climate Parochialism After Sandy. Krueckeberg
Doctoral Conference in Urban Studies, Urban Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers
University, New Brunswick, NJ: March 10.
How global city labor markets shape urban climate politics. Work in a Warming World
interdisciplinary conference, York University, Toronto: November 30.
Climate change and the future of the capitalist city: The legacy of post-war futurology in
contemporary urban climate politics. Association of American geographers annual
conference, Los Angeles: April 11.
Climate change and the future of the capitalist city: The legacy of post-war futurology in
contemporary urban climate politics. Critical Climate Workshop, University of
Minnesota, April 5.
Odious analogies: Public social science and the politics of climate change. Roundtable
paper. American Sociological Association annual meeting, Denver: August 17.
Is there an urban politics of climate change? Distributed paper. International Sociological
Association Forum of Sociology, Buenos Aires: August 1. (Unable to attend.)
Urban climate politics and democracy (in search of the missing “win-win”). New York
University Department of Sociology spring conference, April 20.
Urban climate politics and democracy (in search of the missing “win-win”). Association
of American Geographers annual conference, New York: February 27.
Two ships passing in the night: The urban politics of climate change in São Paulo.
NYLON annual conference, London: April 2.
“The Creative Resistance of Cocalero Politics: Pragmatist theory and the labour practices
of Bolivia’s coca growers”, New York University Department of Sociology spring
conference. New York: April 9.
Other invited presentations and talks
The global urban street ﬁght and the politics of climate change. NYU-School of
Professional Studies Center for Global Affairs. October 30.
A Tale of Two Sandys. Invited by the Federal Emergency Management Agency ﬁeld
ofﬁce in Forest Hills, Queens. With Erin Bergren. January 17.
Class, Carbon and the City: The rise, stagnation, and re-incarnation of low-carbon
urbanism. Seminar on historical and political sociology at the University of São Paulo,
Department of Sociology, São Paulo. May 15.
The political sociology of climate change. Lecture. Jeff Manza’s undergraduate class,
Introduction to Sociology, New York University. New York. November 28.
Why student activism? Presentation. Andrew Ross’s undergraduate class, Introduction to
Social and Cultural Analysis, New York University. New York. November 17.
Contradictions of São Paulo’s urban climate politics. Seminar discussion.
Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas Espaciais, São José dos Campos (Brazil). August 5.
Book discussion: Notes From Canada’s Young Activists. Holy Blossom Conference on Social
Action. Toronto. May 4.
Other professional service and activities (workshops, research, writing, editing)
2012-present Reviewer: American Journal of Sociology, Social Problems, Sociological Theory.
2010-present Member: American Sociological Association, Association of American Geographers,
International Sociological Association.
2008-present Member, NYLON Research Network. (www.nyu.edu/projects/nylon)
Fellow, Hertog Global Strategy Initiative’s summer seminar, “The History and Future of
Climate Change and Global Governance,” Columbia University, New York. May-August
Participant, Johannesburg Workshop in Theory and Criticism: Futures of Nature.
University of the Witwatersrand, Johannesburg. July 1-10.
Participant, Berlin Summer School in Social Sciences. Social Science Research Center
Berlin (WZB) and Berlin Graduate School of Social Science (BGSS). Berlin. 15-30 July.
Editorial assistant, Jeff Manza ed. The Sociology Project: Introducing the Sociological Imagination.
New York: Pearson.
Editorial assistant, Public Culture
Assistant editor and contributor, Social Science Research Council online forum on
Occupy Wall Street (www.possible-futures.org).
Department of Sociology, Graduate Student Association representative, liaison with
GSOC-UAW graduate employee union campaign
Editorial intern, The Walrus magazine, Toronto, January-July.
Editor, McGill Daily, an independent student newspaper, Montreal, May-May.
Features Editor, McGill Daily, an independent student newspaper, Montreal,
September-May.
Languages
English: First language
French: Fluent speaking, reading, and writing
Portuguese: Fluent speaking and reading, advanced writing
Spanish: Advanced speaking and reading, intermediate writing
